question_text:
Let
\[P =

1 & 2 & 0 & 2 \\
-1 & -2 & 1 & 1 \\
1 & 2 & -3 & -7 \\
1 & 2 & -2 & -4

Then rank of \( P \) equals

\[P = 
\begin{bmatrix}
\alpha & \beta \\
\gamma & 0
\end{bmatrix}\]
and \(P^{-1} = P\). Then
Let \(m > 1\). The volume of the solid generated by revolving the region between the y-axis and the curve \(xy = 4\), \(1 \leq y \leq m\), about the y-axis is \(15\pi\). The value of \(m\) is
Consider the region \(S\) enclosed by the surface \(z = y^2\) and the planes \(z = 1, x = 0, x = 1, y = -1\) and \(y = 1\). The volume of \(S\) is

Let \( X \) be a discrete random variable with the moment generating function
\[M_X(t) = e^{0.5\left(e^{t-1}\right)}, \quad t \in \mathbb{R}.\]
Then \( P(X \leq 1) \) equals

\[P(E|F) + P(F|E) = 1, \quad P(E \cap F) = \frac{2}{9} \text{ and } P(F) < P(E).\]
Then \( P(E) \) equals

\[f(x) = \frac{1}{(2 + x^2)^{3/2}}, \quad x \in \mathbb{R}.\]

The probability density function of a random variable \( X \) is given by
\[f(x) = 
\begin{cases}
\alpha x^{\alpha - 1}, & 0 < x < 1 \\
0, & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}, \quad \alpha > 0.\]
Then the distribution of the random variable \( Y = \log_e X^{-2\alpha} \) is
Let \( X_1, X_2, \ldots \) be a sequence of i.i.d. \( N(0,1) \) random variables. Then, as \( n \to \infty \), \( \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n X_i^2 \) converges in probability to

Let \( (X, Y) \) have the joint probability density function
\[f(x, y) = 
\begin{cases} 
\frac{1}{2} y^2 e^{-x}, & \text{if } 0 < y < x < \infty, \\
0, & \text{otherwise}.
\end{cases}\]
Then \( P(Y < 1 | X = 3) \) equals

Let \( X_1, X_2, \ldots \) be a sequence of i.i.d. random variables having the probability density function
\[f(x) = 
\begin{cases} 
\frac{1}{B(6,4)} x^5 (1-x)^3, & 0 < x < 1, \\
0, & \text{otherwise}.
\end{cases}\]
Let \( Y_i = \frac{X_i}{1-X_i} \) and \( U_n = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n Y_i \). If the distribution of \( \sqrt{n(U_n - 2)} \alpha \) converges to \( N(0,1) \) as \( n \to \infty \), then a possible value of \( \alpha \) is

Let \( X_1, \ldots, X_n \) be a random sample from a population with the probability density function
\[f(x | \theta) = 
\begin{cases} 
4e^{-4(x-\theta)}, & x > \theta, \\
0, & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}, \quad \theta \in \mathbb{R}.\]
If \( T_n = \min \{X_1, \ldots, X_n\} \), then

options.A: \( T_n \) is unbiased and consistent estimator of \( \theta \)
options.B: \( T_n \) is biased and consistent estimator of \( \theta \)
options.C: \( T_n \) is unbiased but NOT consistent estimator of \( \theta \)
options.D: \( T_n \) is NEITHER unbiased NOR consistent estimator of \( \theta \)

question_text:
Let \( X_1, \ldots, X_n \) be i.i.d. random variables with the probability density function
\[f(x) = 
\begin{cases} 
e^{-x}, & x > 0, \\
0, & \text{otherwise}.
\end{cases}\]
If \( X_{(n)} = \max \{X_1, \ldots, X_n\} \), then \(\lim_{n \to \infty} P(X_{(n)} - \log_e n \leq 2)\) equals
Let \( X \) and \( Y \) be two independent \( N(0,1) \) random variables. Then \( P(0 < X^2 + Y^2 < 4) \) equals

Let \( X \) be a random variable with the cumulative distribution function
\[F(x) =
\begin{cases} 
0, & x < 0, \\
\frac{x}{8}, & 0 \leq x < 2, \\
\frac{x^2}{16}, & 2 \leq x < 4, \\
1, & x \geq 4.
\end{cases}\]
Then \( E(X) \) equals

Let \( X_1, \ldots, X_n \) be a random sample from a population with the probability density function
\[f(x) = \frac{1}{2\theta} e^{-|x|/\theta}, x \in \mathbb{R}, \theta > 0.\]
For a suitable constant \( K \), the critical region of the most powerful test for testing \( H_0 : \theta = 1 \) against \( H_1 : \theta = 2 \) is of the form

Let \( X_1, \ldots, X_n, X_{n+1}, X_{n+2}, \ldots, X_{n+m} \) (\( n > 4, m > 4 \)) be a random sample from \( N(\mu, \sigma^2) \); 
\( \mu \in \mathbb{R}, \sigma > 0 \). If \( \bar{X}_1 = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n X_i \) and \( \bar{X}_2 = \frac{1}{m-2} \sum_{i=n+1}^{n+m-2} X_i \), then the distribution of the random variable
\[T = \frac{X_{n+m} - X_{n+m-1}}{\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^n (X_i - \bar{X}_1)^2 + \sum_{i=n+1}^{n+m-2} (X_i - \bar{X}_2)^2}}\]
is

Let \( X_1, \ldots, X_n \) (\( n > 1 \)) be a random sample from a Poisson (\(\theta\)) population, \( \theta > 0 \), and 
\[T = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i. \] Then the uniformly minimum variance unbiased estimator of \( \theta^2 \) is

Let \( X \) be a random variable whose probability mass functions \( f(x|H_0) \) (under the null hypothesis \( H_0 \)) and \( f(x|H_1) \) (under the alternative hypothesis \( H_1 \)) are given by

\[\begin{array}{c|c|c|c}
X = x & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\
\hline
f(x|H_0) & 0.4 & 0.3 & 0.2 & 0.1 \\
f(x|H_1) & 0.1 & 0.2 & 0.3 & 0.4 \\
\end{array}\]

For testing the null hypothesis \( H_0 : X \sim f(x|H_0) \) against the alternative hypothesis \( H_1 : X \sim f(x|H_1) \), consider the test given by: Reject \( H_0 \) if \( X > \frac{3}{2} \). If \( \alpha = \) size of the test and \( \beta = \) power of the test, then
Let \( X_1, \ldots, X_n \) be a random sample from a \( N(2\theta, \theta^2) \) population, \( \theta > 0 \). A consistent estimator for \( \theta \) is

An institute purchases laptops from either vendor \( V_1 \) or vendor \( V_2 \) with equal probability. The lifetimes (in years) of laptops from vendor \( V_1 \) have a \( U(0,4) \) distribution, and the lifetimes (in years) of laptops from vendor \( V_2 \) have an \( Exp(1/2) \) distribution. If a randomly selected laptop in the institute has lifetime more than two years, then the probability that it was supplied by vendor \( V_2 \) is

Let \( y(x) \) be the solution to the differential equation
\[x^4 \frac{dy}{dx} + 4x^3y + \sin x = 0; \quad y(\pi) = 1, \quad x > 0.\]
Then \( y\left( \frac{\pi}{2} \right) \) is
Let \( a_n = e^{-2n} \sin n \) and \( b_n = e^{-n} n^2 (\sin n)^2 \) for \( n \geq 1 \). Then

options.A: \( \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n \) converges but \( \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n \) does NOT converge
options.B: \( \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n \) converges but \( \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n \) does NOT converge

question_text:
Let
\[f(x) = 
\begin{cases} 
x \sin^2 (1/x), & x \neq 0, \\ 
0, & x = 0, 
\end{cases}\]
and \( g(x) = 
\begin{cases} 
x (\sin x) \sin (1/x), & x \neq 0, \\ 
0, & x = 0. 
\end{cases}\)
Then

options.A: \( f \) is differentiable at 0 but \( g \) is NOT differentiable at 0
options.B: \( g \) is differentiable at 0 but \( f \) is NOT differentiable at 0
options.C: \( f \) and \( g \) are both differentiable at 0
options.D: NEITHER \( f \) NOR \( g \) is differentiable at 0

question_text: Let \( f : [0,4] \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) be a twice differentiable function. Further, let \( f(0) = 1 \), \( f(2) = 2 \) and \( f(4) = 3 \). Then

options.A: there does NOT exist any \( x_1 \in (0,2) \) such that \( f'(x_1) = \frac{1}{2} \)
options.B: there exist \( x_2 \in (0,2) \) and \( x_3 \in (2,4) \) such that \( f'(x_2) = f'(x_3) \)

question_text: Let \( f(x,y) = x^2 - 400xy^2 \) for all \( (x,y) \in \mathbb{R}^2 \). Then \( f \) attains its

options.A: local minimum at \( (0,0) \) but NOT at \( (1,1) \)
options.B: local minimum at \( (1,1) \) but NOT at \( (0,0) \)
options.D: local minimum NEITHER at \( (0,0) \) NOR at \( (1,1) \)

question_text:
Let \( y(x) \) be the solution to the differential equation
\[4 \frac{d^2y}{dx^2} + 12 \frac{dy}{dx} + 9y = 0, \quad y(0) = 1, \quad y'(0) = -4.\]
Then \( y(1) \) equals

Let \( g : [0,2] \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) be defined by
\[g(x) = \int_{0}^{x}(x-t)e^t \, dt.\]
The area between the curve \( y = g''(x) \) and the \( x \)-axis over the interval \([0,2]\) is

Let \( P \) be a \( 3 \times 3 \) singular matrix such that \( P \vec{v} = \vec{v} \) for a nonzero vector \( \vec{v} \) and
\[P \begin{bmatrix}
1 \\
0 \\
-1
\end{bmatrix} =
\begin{bmatrix}
2/5 \\
0 \\
-2/5
\end{bmatrix}.\]
Then

options.A: If \( a = b \), the solutions of the system lie on the line \( x + y = 1/2 \)
options.B: If \( a = -b \), the solutions of the system lie on the line \( y - x = 1/2 \)
options.C: If \( a \neq \pm b \), the system has no solution
options.D: If \( a \neq \pm b \), the system has a unique solution

question_text:
For \( n \geq 1 \), let
\[a_n =
\begin{cases}
n \, 2^{-n}, & \text{if } n \text{ is odd,} \\
-3^{-n}, & \text{if } n \text{ is even.}
\end{cases}\]
Which of the following statements is (are) TRUE?

options.D: There exists \( m > 0 \) such that \(\lim_{x \to \infty} x^m f(x)\) does NOT exist.

question_text: For \( x \in \mathbb{R} \), define \( f(x) = \cos(\pi x) + \left[ x^2 \right] \) and \( g(x) = \sin(\pi x) \). Which of the following statements is (are) TRUE?

options.C: \( f(x) + g(x) \) is continuous at \( x = 2 \)
options.D: \( f(x) \, g(x) \) is continuous at \( x = 2 \)

question_text: Let \( E \) and \( F \) be two events with \( 0 < P(E) < 1, \, 0 < P(F) < 1 \) and \( P(E | F) > P(E) \). Which of the following statements is (are) TRUE?

Let \( X_1, \ldots, X_n \, (n > 1) \) be a random sample from a \( U(2\theta - 1, 2\theta + 1) \) population, \( \theta \in \mathbb{R} \), and \( Y_i = \min\{X_1, \ldots, X_n\}, \, Y_n = \max\{X_1, \ldots, X_n\} \). Which of the following statistics is (are) maximum likelihood estimator (s) of \( \theta \)?

options.D: Every statistic \( T(X_1, \ldots, X_n) \) satisfying \( \frac{(Y_n - 1)}{2} < T(X_1, \ldots, X_n) < \frac{(Y_i + 1)}{2} \)

question_text: Let \( X_1, \ldots, X_n \) be a random sample from a \( N(0, \sigma^2) \) population, \( \sigma > 0 \). Which of the following testing problems has (have) the region \( \left\{ (x_1, \ldots, x_n) \in \mathbb{R}^n : \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i^2 \geq \chi_{a, a}^2 \right\} \) as the most powerful critical region of level \( \alpha \)?
Let \( X_1, \ldots, X_n \) be a random sample from a \( N(0, 2\theta^2) \) population, \( \theta > 0 \). Which of the following statements is (are) TRUE?

options.B: \( (X_1, \ldots, X_n) \) is sufficient but NOT complete
options.D: \( \frac{1}{2n} \sum_{i=1}^n X_i^2 \) is the uniformly minimum variance unbiased estimator for \( \theta^2 \)

question_text:
Let \( X_1, \ldots, X_n \) be a random sample from a population with the probability density function
\[f(x|\theta) = 
\begin{cases} 
\theta e^{-\theta x}, & x > 0, \\
0, & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}, \quad \theta > 0.\]
Which of the following is (are) \( 100(1 - \alpha)\% \) confidence interval(s) for \( \theta \)?

The cumulative distribution function of a random variable \( X \) is given by
\[F(x) = 
\begin{cases} 
0, & x < 2, \\
\frac{1}{10} \left( x^2 - \frac{7}{3} \right), & 2 \leq x < 3, \\
1, & x \geq 3.
\end{cases}\]
Which of the following statements is (are) TRUE?

Let \( X_1, \ldots, X_{10} \) be a random sample from a \( N(3,12) \) population. Suppose \( Y_i = \frac{1}{6} \sum_{i=1}^{6} X_i \) and 
\[Y_2 = \frac{1}{4} \sum_{i=7}^{10} X_i. \quad \text{If} \quad \left( \frac{(Y_1 - Y_2)^2}{\alpha} \right) \text{has a } \chi^2 \text{distribution, then the value of } \alpha \text{ is} \underline{\hspace{5cm}}.\]

Let \( X \) be a continuous random variable with the probability density function 
\[f(x) = 
\begin{cases} 
\frac{2x}{9}, & 0 < x < 3, \\
0, & \text{otherwise.}
\end{cases}\]
Then the upper bound of \( P(|X - 2| > 1) \) using Chebyshev's inequality is \underline{\hspace{5cm}}.

Let \( X \) and \( Y \) be continuous random variables with the joint probability density function 
\[f(x, y) = 
\begin{cases} 
e^{(x+y)}, & -\infty < x, \, y < 0, \\
0, & \text{otherwise.}
\end{cases}\]
Then \( P(X < Y) = \underline{\hspace{5cm}} \).

Let \( X \) and \( Y \) be continuous random variables with the joint probability density function 
\[f(x, y) = \frac{1}{2\pi} e^{-(x^2 + y^2)/2}, \, (x, \, y) \in \mathbb{R}^2.\]
Then \( P(X > 0, \, Y < 0) = \underline{\hspace{5cm}} \).

Let \( Y \) be a \( Bin\left(\frac{72}{3}, \frac{1}{3}\right) \) random variable. Using normal approximation to binomial distribution, an approximate value of \( P(22 \leq Y \leq 28) \) is \underline{\hspace{5cm}}.

Let \( X \) be a Bin \( (2, p) \) random variable and \( Y \) be a Bin \( (4, p) \) random variable, \( 0 < p < 1 \). If 
\[P(X \geq 1) = \frac{5}{9}, \text{ then } P(Y \geq 1) = \underline{\quad }\]

Consider the linear transformation
\[T(x, y, z) = (2x + y + z, x + z, 3x + 2y + z).\]
The rank of \( T \) is ______.

The value of 
\[\lim_{n \to \infty} n \left[ e^{-n} \cos(4n) + \sin\left(\frac{1}{4n}\right) \right] \text{ is ______}\]
Let \( f : [0, 13] \to \mathbb{R} \) be defined by \( f(x) = x^{13} - e^{-x} + 5x + 6 \). The minimum value of the function \( f \) on \([0, 13]\) is ______.
Consider a differentiable function \( f \) on \([0, 1]\) with the derivative \( f'(x) = 2\sqrt{2x} \). The arc length of the curve \( y = f(x), 0 \leq x \leq 1 \), is ______.

Let \( m \) be a real number such that \( m > 1 \). If
\[\int_{1}^{m} \int_{0}^{1} \int_{\sqrt{x}}^{1} e^{y^3} dy \, dx \, dz = e - 1,\]
then \( m = \) ______.

Let
\[P = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & -3 & 3 \\
0 & -5 & 6 \\
0 & -3 & 4
\end{bmatrix}.\]
The product of the eigen values of \( P^{-1} \) is ______.

The value of the real number \( m \) in the following equation
\[\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\sqrt{2-x^2}}{x} \left( x^2 + y^2 \right) dy \, dx = \int_{m\pi/2}^{\pi/2} \int_{0}^{\sqrt{2}} r^3 \, dr \, d\theta\]
is ______

Let \( a_1 = 1 \) and \( a_n = 2 - \frac{1}{n} \) for \( n \geq 2 \). Then
\[\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \left( \frac{1}{a_n^2} - \frac{1}{a_{n+1}^2} \right)\]
converges to ______

Let \( X_1, X_2, \ldots \) be a sequence of i.i.d. random variables with the probability density function
\[f(x) = 
\begin{cases} 
4x^2 e^{-2x}, & x > 0, \\
0, & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}\]
and let \( S_n = \sum_{i=1}^{n} X_i \). Then \(\lim_{n \to \infty} P \left( S_n \leq \frac{3n}{2} + \sqrt{3n} \right)\) is ______

Let \( X \) and \( Y \) be continuous random variables with the joint probability density function
\[f(x, y) = 
\begin{cases} 
\frac{c \cdot x^2}{y^3}, & 0 < x < 1, \, y > 1, \\
0, & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}\]
where \( c \) is a suitable constant. Then \( E(X) = \) ______
Two points are chosen at random on a line segment of length 9 cm. The probability that the distance between these two points is less than 3 cm is ______

Let \( X \) be a continuous random variable with the probability density function
\[f(x) = 
\begin{cases} 
\frac{x+1}{2}, & -1 < x < 1, \\
0, & \text{otherwise}.
\end{cases}\]
Then \( P\left(\frac{1}{4} < X^2 < \frac{1}{2}\right) = \underline{\hspace{3cm}} \)
If \( X \) is a \( U(0,1) \) random variable, then \( P\left(\min(X, 1-X) \leq \frac{1}{4}\right) = \underline{\hspace{3cm}} \)

In a colony all families have at least one child. The probability that a randomly chosen family from this colony has exactly \( k \) children is \((0.5)^k ; k = 1, 2, \ldots \). A child is either a male or a female with equal probability. The probability that such a family consists of at least one male child and at least one female child is \(\underline{\hspace{3cm}}\)
